awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: The Master Print: Investigating and Addressing Vulnerabilities in Fingerprint-based Authentication Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to investigate the security of fingerprint authentication systems, especially those using partial fingerprints. A number of consumer electronic devices, such as smartphones, are beginning to incorporate fingerprint sensors for user authentication. The sensors embedded in these devices are generally very small and the resulting images are, therefore, limited in size. To compensate for the limited size, these devices often acquire multiple partial impressions (templates) of a single finger during enrollment to ensure that at least one of them will successfully match with the image obtained from the user during authentication. In some cases, the user may even be allowed to enroll multiple fingers, and the templates pertaining to these multiple fingers are associated with the same identity (i.e., one user). A user is deemed to be successfully authenticated if the partial fingerprint obtained during authentication matches with any one of the stored templates. 

This project is investigating the possibility of generating a "Master Print," a synthetic or real partial fingerprint that serendipitously matches with a large number of partial impressions pertaining to multiple users. This is akin to having a Master Password that can unlock a diverse set of user accounts. In this regard, the following tasks are being conducted: (a) Analyzing the vulnerability of fingerprint authentication systems that use partial fingerprints by developing methods to generate Master Prints; (b) Models for computing the distinctiveness or uniqueness of partial fingerprints compared to full prints; (c) Methods for mitigating the vulnerability associated with the adversarial use of Master Prints.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
What vulnerability in biometrics was uncovered as part of this research?
A number of consumer electronic devices, such as smartphones, are beginning to incorporate fingerprint sensors for user authentication. The sensors embedded in these devices are generally small and the resulting images are, therefore, limited in size (partial fingerprints). To compensate for the limited size, these devices often acquire multiple partial impressions of a single finger during enrollment to ensure that at least one of them will successfully match with the image obtained from the user during authentication. This introduces a vulnerability that needs to be carefully addressed.
Must smartphone developers use different fingerprint systems? How can these improve?
Smartphone developers can use effective anti-spoofing schemes; carefully select the number and nature of partial impressions of a user during enrollment; improve the resolution of small-sized sensors to facilitate extraction of more discriminative features; develop matchers that utilize both minutiae and texture information; and design more effective fusion schemes to combine the information presented by multiple partial impressions of a user.
How likely is it for someone’s phone to be targeted this way?
It is not very easy. In the context of smartphones, the vulnerability can be realized only if the MasterPrints are converted to actual physical artifacts (known as spoofs). Further, the smartphone must enroll a large number of fingerprint impressions per user corresponding to different portions of a single finger or multiple fingers. 
What is the best security system, today, to access a smartphone?
We would say multi-factor authentication schemes, that judiciously combine biometrics with pins or pass codes. 
What was your motivation for the study?
In this research we investigated the possibility of generating MasterPrints. A MasterPrint - a term that we coined -  is a fingerprint impression that fortuitously matches against a large number of fingerprints pertaining to different people. This is akin to a Master Password that unlocks a large number of accounts, or a commonly used password such as “1234”. Our motivation was to study the loss in distinctiveness of a person’s fingerprint when only a small portion of it is used for authentication. 

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2021
Modified by: Arun A Ross

What vulnerability in biometrics was uncovered as part of this research?
A number of consumer electronic devices, such as smartphones, are beginning to incorporate fingerprint sensors for user authentication. The sensors embedded in these devices are generally small and the resulting images are, therefore, limited in size (partial fingerprints). To compensate for the limited size, these devices often acquire multiple partial impressions of a single finger during enrollment to ensure that at least one of them will successfully match with the image obtained from the user during authentication. This introduces a vulnerability that needs to be carefully addressed.
Must smartphone developers use different fingerprint systems? How can these improve?
Smartphone developers can use effective anti-spoofing schemes; carefully select the number and nature of partial impressions of a user during enrollment; improve the resolution of small-sized sensors to facilitate extraction of more discriminative features; develop matchers that utilize both minutiae and texture information; and design more effective fusion schemes to combine the information presented by multiple partial impressions of a user.
How likely is it for someone’s phone to be targeted this way?
It is not very easy. In the context of smartphones, the vulnerability can be realized only if the MasterPrints are converted to actual physical artifacts (known as spoofs). Further, the smartphone must enroll a large number of fingerprint impressions per user corresponding to different portions of a single finger or multiple fingers. 
What is the best security system, today, to access a smartphone?
We would say multi-factor authentication schemes, that judiciously combine biometrics with pins or pass codes. 
What was your motivation for the study?
In this research we investigated the possibility of generating MasterPrints. A MasterPrint - a term that we coined -  is a fingerprint impression that fortuitously matches against a large number of fingerprints pertaining to different people. This is akin to a Master Password that unlocks a large number of accounts, or a commonly used password such as "1234". Our motivation was to study the loss in distinctiveness of a person’s fingerprint when only a small portion of it is used for authentication.
